awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: GOALI: High-Impact Multiscale Physicochemical Advancements for the Prediction of Transient Dermal Absorption
awd_abstract_narration:
This GOALI project will advance the science of skin penetration and, in particular, the prediction of transient dermal absorption for human exposure to chemical agents, whether they are beneficial or hazardous.  The former case includes topical drugs and cosmetic benefit agents; the latter includes aerosolized pesticides encountered by farm workers, airborne pollutants encountered by residents in city environments, and trace chemicals encountered by workers in settings such as concrete and metal working.  Modeling and simulation has recently become a component of the US FDA’s approval process for generic drug products, which reduces cost and accelerates approval of these products. Global regulatory agencies including US NIOSH have increasingly included modeling as part of their dermal risk assessment process.  This project will address two vexing issues plaguing predictions of transient skin absorption:  (1) slowly reversible binding of chemicals to skin proteins (especially keratin) complicates the uptake and release profiles of many commonly-encountered chemicals including topical steroids; and (2) gradual dissolution of solid particles deposited on the skin surface or within hair follicles affects absorption of drugs from gels and ointments and dermal absorption of heavy metals leached from airborne pollutants.  Results from the project will be incorporated into a publicly available, spreadsheet-based skin penetration program and also a state-of-the-art simulation code for dermal absorption maintained by the GOALI industrial partner, Procter & Gamble.  Parts of the research will be incorporated into undergraduate and graduate training in the cosmetic science area at the University of Cincinnati.  The educational plan also specifically targets undergraduate research experiences for undergraduate women and underrepresented minority students.

This project entails: (1) experimental measurement and broad parameterization of rate constants for keratin binding in the outer skin barrier cells (corneocytes) supported by a rigorous theoretical framework; and (2) development and implementation of interfacial mass transport relationships capable of representing absorption of precipitated solids on the skin.  Intellectual merit lies in the identification and resolution of important strategic gaps in the current understanding of dermal absorption, which block progress in these two areas involving multiphase and multiscale transport.  A central element of the project is multiscale modeling based on two stages of rigorous coarse graining - from ultrastructural (intracellular) to microscopic (intercellular) to macroscopic (tissue) scales - in resolving slow reversible binding of permeating molecules to stratum corneum keratin, which dramatically affects transport rates.  The project will define the reservoir capacity of the skin barrier in theoretically rigorous and pragmatically useful terms, which will open the way to a broad-spectrum ability to accurately predict transient dermal absorption outcomes.  The detailed treatment of dissolution-limited absorption will finally resolve dramatically different absorption rates observed for ostensibly similar molecules that have long baffled pharmaceutical and consumer product development efforts and risk assessments related to chemical exposures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS

por.por_cntn:
GOALI Award #2124495 (Kasting, PI) was a collaborative effort between two academic investigators and researchers at the Procter & Gamble Company to strengthen the computational methods used to estimate absorption of a wide range of chemicals through the skin.  These methods have value in many areas of commercial and industrial significance, including dermatological and transdermal drug development and cosmetic and personal care product development, as well as for estimating human health consequences arising from occupational chemical exposures. 

The project explored two poorly understood aspects of transient absorption of chemicals following small exposures to the skin, such as those arising from intentional exposures to cosmetic products or from accidental exposures to hazardous substances.  Aim 1 involved determining how the kinetics of reversible binding of solutes to keratin proteins in the skin’s outer, barrier layer (the stratum corneum, SC) impacts the rate at which chemicals cross this barrier.  Aim 2 involved better characterizing the impact of solvent selection and crystallization of dissolved solutes on the skin surface on their eventual uptake into the skin.  Results are summarized below. 

Aim 1.  Equilibrium binding of solutes to skin keratins has been well characterized and is an accepted component of modern skin permeation models.  Such binding increases the partition coefficient of solutes in the SC, Ksc/w, but reduces the effective (or macroscopic) diffusivity, Dsc.  It does not impact steady-state skin permeability, as the product Dsc ´ Ksc/w remains unchanged from that of freely diffusing solute.  The membrane presents as a homogeneous medium with diffusive time lag, tL = (hsc)2 / (6 Dsc).  Thus, time lags for permeation of solutes through the membrane are increased in a predictable manner.

The situation becomes more complex if binding equilibrium is not achieved within the time frame of the exposure.  Permeation profiles for solutes applied to the SC are changed in a manner that is dependent on the microscopic structure of the tissue.  In fact, since the protein phase of the tissue is itself complex, a third length scale, which we call “ultrascopic”, comes into play.  Ultrascopic binding kinetics of solutes to keratin microfibrils can be measured in the laboratory using powdered keratin substrates, but the connection between these measurements and macroscopic solute diffusion across the SC was heretofore a mystery.

We developed a novel framework for linking ultrascopic, microscopic and macroscopic transport phenomena for solutes diffusing in the SC.  Furthermore, we established experimentally that slowly reversible binding of solutes to SC keratins cannot be the source of the SC reservoir function of topical steroids reported decades ago.  Rather, it is more likely that supersaturation of the tissue, followed by precipitation of solute within the SC, leads to the observed delayed release effects.

Aim 2.  Toxicologists in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic communities continue to seek improved ways of assessing the risk associated with products applied to the skin or topical exposures to environmental contaminants.  In vitro permeation tests (IVPTs) using human skin or suitable alternatives as the test membrane are often conducted as part of these efforts.  Optimization of the test conditions for such studies is an ongoing process.  Results are highly dependent on formulation, dose and exposure conditions.  There is an increasing emphasis on the use of mathematical models to interpret the data and relate it to in vivo human exposures.  We are heavily involved in this effort.

Pursuant to the above, we studied the disposition of both hydrophilic (water-loving) and lipophilic (lipid-loving) compounds applied to the skin in small amounts from simple, volatile solvent systems.  We included in our studies several weak acids and bases and their salts.  We showed that solute deposition into the skin was favored by low surface energy solvents that spread effectively on skin, but were not so volatile that they evaporated before fully depositing their contents.  Ethanol-water mixtures were particularly effective, even when applied at levels well below those that disrupt SC lipids.  Solid precipitates on the skin surface gradually redissolved and penetrated the skin.  In the case of deposited weak electrolyte salts, the penetration rate was consistent with a mechanism in which a small flux of protons arising from the SC acid mantle (as H3O+) continuously neutralized the deposited salt, allowing the free acid or base form of the compound to slowly dissolve into the SC lipids.  The analysis was applied to a large IVPT database. 

The primary, immediate use for the developed models is as components of a computational toolbox (DigiSkin) for both product development and risk assessment for industrial partner, Procter & Gamble.  However, the developed algorithms are published in the open literature and are freely available to the scientific community, e.g. as MoBi add-ons to the PK-Sim pharmacokinetic model on the Open Systems Pharmacology platform and as the NIOSH Finite Dose Skin Permeation calculator, https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/skin/finiteSkinPermCalc.html.  Example scientific outputs from the project are explored in the attached images.

 


Last Modified: 10/02/2024
Modified by: Gerald Kasting

Images (1 of )
  • Schematic diagram of the three levels of homogenization (ultrascopic, microscopic and macroscopic) represented in the developed skin diffusion model.
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Gerald Kasting
    Figure 1
  • Light micrographs of test solutes deposited in 10 uL aliquots onto human epidermal membrane from four solvents. Doses were 50 ug for niacinamide, 10 ug for caffeine, 30 ug for testosterone and 50 ug for geraniol. Images were captured by transmitted light under cross-polarized filters.
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Gerald Kasting
    Figure 3
  • Schematic diagram for interfacial resistance at the vehicle-SC interface for a solvent-deposited solid. The diagram depicts small particles (d = ~3-5 um) deposited on a skin surface with a root-mean-square roughness of 25 um. The interfacial resistance resides in the boundary layer Deltalip.
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Gerald Kasting
    Figure 4
  • Comparison of the predicted receptor fluid amounts of three solutes from Hewitt et al. 2019 using the final developed model (solid green), Model 4.0 with the dose pH (orange dots) and Model 4.0 at a pH of 5.5 (blue dashes). The symbols represent experimental measurements and their standard deviation
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Gerald Kasting
    Figure 6
  • Schematic illustration of the surface/SC interface of a weak electrolyte deposited on skin in a partially ionized state. The surface roughness depicted in Figure 4 is still present, but has been omitted here for clarity.
    Elsevier
    Copyrighted
    Gerald Kasting
    Figure 5
  • Scheme indicating the role of the present analysis vis-�-vis previously published work in connecting ultrascopic, microscopic and macroscopic descriptions of solute�keratin binding in the SC. Transport and partitioning variables at each level are represented with 0, 1 or 2 overbars, respectively.
    Elsevier

por.por_txt_cntn:
GOALI Award #2124495 (Kasting, PI) was a collaborative effort between two academic investigators and researchers at the Procter & Gamble Company to strengthen the computational methods used to estimate absorption of a wide range of chemicals through the skin. These methods have value in many areas of commercial and industrial significance, including dermatological and transdermal drug development and cosmetic and personal care product development, as well as for estimating human health consequences arising from occupational chemical exposures.


The project explored two poorly understood aspects of transient absorption of chemicals following small exposures to the skin, such as those arising from intentional exposures to cosmetic products or from accidental exposures to hazardous substances. Aim 1 involved determining how the kinetics of reversible binding of solutes to keratin proteins in the skins outer, barrier layer (the stratum corneum, SC) impacts the rate at which chemicals cross this barrier. Aim 2 involved better characterizing the impact of solvent selection and crystallization of dissolved solutes on the skin surface on their eventual uptake into the skin. Results are summarized below.


Aim 1. Equilibrium binding of solutes to skin keratins has been well characterized and is an accepted component of modern skin permeation models. Such binding increases the partition coefficient of solutes in the SC, Ksc/w, but reduces the effective (or macroscopic) diffusivity, Dsc. It does not impact steady-state skin permeability, as the product Dsc  Ksc/w remains unchanged from that of freely diffusing solute. The membrane presents as a homogeneous medium with diffusive time lag, tL = (hsc)2 / (6 Dsc). Thus, time lags for permeation of solutes through the membrane are increased in a predictable manner.


The situation becomes more complex if binding equilibrium is not achieved within the time frame of the exposure. Permeation profiles for solutes applied to the SC are changed in a manner that is dependent on the microscopic structure of the tissue. In fact, since the protein phase of the tissue is itself complex, a third length scale, which we call ultrascopic, comes into play. Ultrascopic binding kinetics of solutes to keratin microfibrils can be measured in the laboratory using powdered keratin substrates, but the connection between these measurements and macroscopic solute diffusion across the SC was heretofore a mystery.


We developed a novel framework for linking ultrascopic, microscopic and macroscopic transport phenomena for solutes diffusing in the SC. Furthermore, we established experimentally that slowly reversible binding of solutes to SC keratins cannot be the source of the SC reservoir function of topical steroids reported decades ago. Rather, it is more likely that supersaturation of the tissue, followed by precipitation of solute within the SC, leads to the observed delayed release effects.


Aim 2. Toxicologists in the pharmaceutical and cosmetic communities continue to seek improved ways of assessing the risk associated with products applied to the skin or topical exposures to environmental contaminants. In vitro permeation tests (IVPTs) using human skin or suitable alternatives as the test membrane are often conducted as part of these efforts. Optimization of the test conditions for such studies is an ongoing process. Results are highly dependent on formulation, dose and exposure conditions. There is an increasing emphasis on the use of mathematical models to interpret the data and relate it to in vivo human exposures. We are heavily involved in this effort.


Pursuant to the above, we studied the disposition of both hydrophilic (water-loving) and lipophilic (lipid-loving) compounds applied to the skin in small amounts from simple, volatile solvent systems. We included in our studies several weak acids and bases and their salts. We showed that solute deposition into the skin was favored by low surface energy solvents that spread effectively on skin, but were not so volatile that they evaporated before fully depositing their contents. Ethanol-water mixtures were particularly effective, even when applied at levels well below those that disrupt SC lipids. Solid precipitates on the skin surface gradually redissolved and penetrated the skin. In the case of deposited weak electrolyte salts, the penetration rate was consistent with a mechanism in which a small flux of protons arising from the SC acid mantle (as H3O+) continuously neutralized the deposited salt, allowing the free acid or base form of the compound to slowly dissolve into the SC lipids. The analysis was applied to a large IVPT database.


The primary, immediate use for the developed models is as components of a computational toolbox (DigiSkin) for both product development and risk assessment for industrial partner, Procter & Gamble. However, the developed algorithms are published in the open literature and are freely available to the scientific community, e.g. as MoBi add-ons to the PK-Sim pharmacokinetic model on the Open Systems Pharmacology platform and as the NIOSH Finite Dose Skin Permeation calculator, https://www.cdc.gov/niosh/topics/skin/finiteSkinPermCalc.html. Example scientific outputs from the project are explored in the attached images.
